Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Since entry of the 2018 order, there has been a **substantial and material change in circumstances** warranting reconsideration of custody and parenting time.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation decision involving joint physical custody and application of a best-interests standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30. It does not involve a post-judgment custody modification based on a claimed substantial and material change in circumstances, nor does it articulate or apply the ‘substantial and material change’ threshold for reopening custody or parenting time orders. Thus it does not provide authority for the proposition that such a change has occurred since a prior order (here, a 2018 order).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002) ... state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce]....”
[The Massachusetts court references this ALI standard but does not adopt it as a Massachusetts rule for custody modification or apply a ‘substantial and material change’ test.]

Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 75 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 131 (2009)
Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 75 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Since entry of the 2018 order, there has been a **substantial and material change in circumstances** warranting reconsideration of custody and parenting time.
Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 75 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct appeal from a divorce judgment, not a post‑judgment modification case, and it does not address the legal standard for modifying a prior custody order based on a substantial and material change in circumstances. Instead, it evaluates the original custody/removal decision under the best‑interests framework and removal case law (Yannas/Mason). There is no discussion of the ‘substantial and material change’ threshold for reconsidering an existing order, so it does not support the proposition that a change since a 2018 order warrants reconsideration of custody and parenting time.
Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 75 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the judge erred by inadequately examining the impact of the move on the children, by allowing them to be uprooted without identifying any distinct advantages that relocation would bring to them, by failing to assess reasonably available alternative arrangements, and by failing to consider whether a shared custody arrangement of the type he envisioned would really work for the parents or the children. Under these circumstances, his decision allowing removal cannot stand.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The minor child’s age, developmental stage, and preferences have changed significantly since entry of the prior order. Sophie is now ten years old, capable of expressing her own views, which the Court may consider under **G.L. c. 208, § 31** and **Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The minor child’s age, developmental stage, and preferences have changed significantly since entry of the prior order. Sophie is now ten years old, capable of expressing her own views, which the Court may consider under **G.L. c. 208, § 31** and **Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a change in the child’s age and developmental stage since a prior order and suggests that Yannas stands for the idea that a now‑older child’s expressed preferences may be considered under G.L. c. 208, § 31. Yannas does not address modification based on changed circumstances or an older child’s evolved preferences; it is a removal/custody case applying the ‘real advantage’ standard and only briefly notes that young children’s wishes generally should not be given particular weight. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition that a ten‑year‑old’s changed developmental status and preferences, post‑judgment, are a basis for considering her views under § 31.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Even if the views of a child as to where he or she should live have constitutional significance (although generally such views of young children should not be given particular weight [see Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 820 (1981)]), and even if in a custody dispute one parent may properly assert constitutional rights of a minor child, this case does not present the constitutional question.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Sophie has **expressed to both parents and to this Court (by letter)** her desire to spend more overnights with her mother. See **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) (child’s preferences, while not controlling, are relevant to best‑interest analysis).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Rosenthal for the general legal principle that a child’s preferences, while not controlling, are relevant to the best‑interest analysis. In this opinion, the Appeals Court explicitly notes the child’s stated preference to live primarily with his mother, explains that such a preference is not dispositive of custody, but treats it as a relevant factor suggesting he could readjust to living with her. That matches the proposition’s characterization of the case.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “In addition, we note that Caleb expressed to the guardian ad litem at the outset of the investigation his preference to reside primarily with his mother, and he reiterated this preference at the conclusion of the investigation, shortly before trial. Although not dispositive of the custody issue, Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738-739 (1996), these factors, at the very least, suggest that Caleb might quickly readjust to living with his mother during the week, and visiting his father on weekends and during part of each school vacation.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Plaintiff and Sophie have **developed a close and healthy relationship** since 2018, demonstrating that greater parenting time with Plaintiff would be in the child’s best interest. See **Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns factual evidence that a particular plaintiff and a child named Sophie developed a close and healthy relationship since 2018 and that greater parenting time would be in that child’s best interests. Hunter v. Rose involves different parties (Hunter and Rose) and different children (Jill and Mia), and its best-interests analysis is specific to those facts. The case does not mention Sophie, 2018, or any analogous factual finding, nor does it establish a legal rule that a later-formed close relationship alone demonstrates that more parenting time is in a child’s best interests; rather, it applies the general Massachusetts best-interests standard to a specific custody dispute. Thus it does not support the specific factual proposition for which it is cited.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Here, the judge found that Jill had developed a strong emotional bond with Hunter from Jill’s birth until she was almost fifteen months old… Jill ‘more likely than not’ was harmed by Rose’s actions… The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance… it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.”}

Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).proposition: These changes—Plaintiff’s improved circumstances, the child’s age and development, the child’s expressed preference, and emotional needs—constitute a **material and substantial change** affecting the child’s welfare. See **Stevens v. Stevens**, 337 Mass. 625 (1958); **Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).support_reasoning: The opinion does address modification of custody based on a change of circumstances, but it does not identify or discuss the specific factors listed in the proposition—improved circumstances of the plaintiff, the child’s age and development, the child’s expressed preference, or emotional needs—as constituting a ‘material and substantial change.’ Instead, the court finds a ‘relevant change of circumstances’ based on the mother’s ability to offer a good, settled home and the fact that the child was no longer in a settled home after being taken to Colorado. Thus, Stevens supports the general requirement of a change of circumstances affecting welfare, but not the specific multifactor formulation stated in the proposition.
Stevens v. Stevens, 337 Mass. 625 (1958).relevant_excerpt: “Manifestly there was a relevant change of circumstances (Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191) adequate to support a change in the order for custody. There was strong assurance of the mother’s ability to offer a good home and the daughter was no longer in a settled home.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: These changes—Plaintiff’s improved circumstances, the child’s age and development, the child’s expressed preference, and emotional needs—constitute a **material and substantial change** affecting the child’s welfare. See **Stevens v. Stevens**, 337 Mass. 625 (1958); **Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: Smith v. McDonald is a paternity/relocation case focused on statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 209C and the limits of judicial authority to order a fit, sole legal parent to return to Massachusetts. It does not discuss or apply any “material and substantial change” standard with respect to modification of custody or visitation based on changes in a child’s circumstances, age, preferences, or emotional needs. Using it as authority for that proposition mischaracterizes the opinion’s subject and holding.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. See ante at 550. As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is 'free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].' Id. at 549-550. As a matter of law, it should make no difference to a parent’s freedom to relocate that another party subsequently files to establish parental rights. See G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), (b)."

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Modification is also supported by principles that prioritize a child’s best interests above prior arrangements when justified by new facts. See **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **White v. LaBelle**, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 719 (1996); **Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case is not a modification proceeding and expressly refuses to apply the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ modification standard. Instead, it reaffirms that initial custody determinations (here under G.L. c. 209C, §10(a)) are governed by the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and discusses statutory factors aimed at preserving stability. It does not stand for the proposition that modification is supported by principles prioritizing the child’s best interests over prior arrangements in light of new facts; rather, it treats best interests as the basic custody standard and declines to treat this as a modification case.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

White v. LaBelle, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 719.raw_text: White v. LaBelle, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 719 (1996)
White v. LaBelle, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 719.proposition: Modification is also supported by principles that prioritize a child’s best interests above prior arrangements when justified by new facts. See **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **White v. LaBelle**, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 719 (1996); **Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981).
White v. LaBelle, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 719.case_name: Priority Finishing Corp. v. LAL Construction Co.
White v. LaBelle, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 719.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the economic loss doctrine in a commercial negligence/bailee context and does not involve child custody, modification of custody, or standards prioritizing a child’s best interests. Nothing in the reasoning or holding addresses family-law modifications or the principle that new facts can justify departing from prior child-related arrangements. Citing this case for that proposition is therefore inaccurate and out of context.
White v. LaBelle, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 719.relevant_excerpt:
Massachusetts follows the traditional rule that “purely economic losses are unrecoverable in tort and strict liability actions in the absence of personal injury or property damage.” FMR Corp. v. Boston Edison Co., 415 Mass. 393, 395 (1993). The defendants contend that this rule should bar the plaintiff from recovery because the plaintiff was merely a bailee of the damaged property, and therefore sustained no damage to property which it owned.
...
Accordingly, we hold that the plaintiff is entitled to maintain this action and to recover any pecuniary losses proximately caused by the defendants’ alleged negligence.

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Modification is also supported by principles that prioritize a child’s best interests above prior arrangements when justified by new facts. See **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **White v. LaBelle**, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 719 (1996); **Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981).
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that decisions on removal must be based on the children’s best interests in light of new circumstances, and that this assessment must include the well‑being and circumstances of the custodial parent, even if that alters existing visitation arrangements. The court reverses because the judge focused too narrowly on preserving prior visitation rather than fully reevaluating best interests, thus endorsing modification of existing arrangements when new facts show a different configuration better serves the children’s interests.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “We consider that factor [difficulty of visitation] not in itself conclusive. The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent, and the determination, therefore, requires that the interests of the mother also be taken into account… We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The child’s best interests are the paramount concern. See **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is centrally about custody and repeatedly frames the analysis in terms of the impact of domestic violence on the child and the need for findings about those effects. While the excerpt provided does not contain the standard Massachusetts formula that “the best interests of the child are paramount,” the court’s discussion that custody decisions must explicitly consider the effects of domestic violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect is consistent with, and functionally applies, the best‑interests‑of‑the‑child standard as the controlling concern in custody determinations.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The child’s best interests are the paramount concern. See **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that in custody determinations the court’s overriding concern must be the best interests and welfare of the children, and it applies that standard to uphold the custody award. This aligns with the proposition that the child’s best interests are the paramount concern in custody cases.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … The ‘best interests’ principle requires that the narrow focus be on the interests of the child.”
